prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As outlined in the science case, we have selected targets with predicted mass-loss rates above 2.E-5 Msol/yr for which peak intensities >0.25 K (or >40 mJy) are expected in the CO J=2-1 and 3-2 transitions.
We have performed simulations to assess the required sensitivity in order to accurately determine the outflow velocity and integrated intensity. The middle panel in Figure 1 shows an example of a simulated profile for a noise level of 0.04 K (2-1) and 0.06 K (3-2) at a smoothened resolution of 1 km/s, and the fitted profile. With these noise levels, the expansion velocity can be recovered with a precision of order of the spectral resolution (i.e. 0.5-0.6 km/s), while the integrated intensity is recovered with 4-5% accuracy.
This shows that we will be able to accurately obtain the expansion velocities and thus can make meaningful comparisons among the stars in the sample and to the velocities of similar targets in the Galaxy, and that the CO modelling effort of the mass-loss rates will not be hampered by the S/N of the data.

In band 6, one spectral window is placed on the CO(2-1) line (230.5 GHz) while the other three are placed (213.0, 215.0, and 228.0 GHz) such as to obtain an estimate of the dust continuum (no line is expected to be strong enough to show up). Of the available correlator modes, the one with a resolution of 488 KHz (or 0.64 km/s) matches the expected outflow velocities of 10-15 km/s.
The velocity resolution in the continuum subbands has been reduced, and there we will reach a noise level of about 0.05 mJy averaging over the subbands, and we expect to detect 3 out of 6 sources at 1300 micron.
Similarly, in band 7 the spectral windows are placed at 345.8 GHz (CO J=3-2) and 333.0, 335.0, and 347.0 GHz to estimate the continuum flux.
The 488 KHz resolution mode corresponds to 0.42 km/s and we may even smooth the spectrum on the CO(3-2) line in order to match the 0.64 km/s resolution in the J=2-1 line, and to improve the S/N.
In the continuum we will reach a noise level of about 0.08 mJy, and expect to detect 5 sources at 860 micron.
The center line velocity of all stars have been assigned a typical LMC velocity of 280 km/s.
None of the targets is close to any of the known molecular clouds in the LMC (NANTEN survey, Fukui et al. 2008) so that contamination by interstellar material in the beam is very unlikely.

The size of the sources are determined by the CO photodissociation radius, and this is a function of the mass-loss rate (MLR), expansion velocity and CO abundance (see the formulae, references and discussion in Groenewegen et al. 1998). For a star with a MLR of 2. E-5 msol/yr this corresponds to an angular diameter of about 0.9" at 50 kpc. For a mass-loss rate 10 times higher it should be about 4 times larger, or less than 4" for all stars in the sample.
This implies that the maximum physical size is clearly smaller than the FoV of the 12m telescopes (so that a single pointing is sufficient) and that the synthesised beam at 230 and 345 GHz (1.6" and 1.0", respectively) using the most compact configuration matches quite well the physical size of the CSE. In some cases, we may even slightly resolve the CSE. This has little influence on the estimate of the peak flux or integrated intensity, but the line shape may start deviating from a parabolic one, in which case the detailed RT modelling will actually shed light on the physical size of the envelope. This is one reason why we prefer to observe both the 2-1 and 3-2 lines.
We have used the ALMA Observation Support Tool (OST) on a point-source and a slightly-extended source (W49 in Leo T template) to simulate the observations. We obtained excellent uv-coverage even for the relatively short integration time (10 minutes) at both frequencies using a resolution of 1.6 arcsec at 230GHz and 1.0 arcsec at 345GHz.
The technical justification for the J=3-2 line is given in the Science Goal of the J=2-1 line as it is nearly identical.

Similar to the observations in Band 6, in band 7 the spectral windows are placed at 345.8 GHz(CO J=3-2) and 333.0, 335.0, and 347.0 GHz to estimate the continuum flux.
The 488 KHz resolution mode corresponds to 0.42 km/s and we may even smooth the spectrum on the CO(3-2) line in order to match the 0.64 km/s resolution in the J=2-1 line, and to improve the S/N.
In the continuum we will reach a noise level of about 0.08 mJy, and expect to detect 5 sources at 860 micron.
The center line velocity of all stars have been assigned a typical LMC velocity of 280 km/s.
None of the targets is close to any of the known molecular clouds in the LMC (NANTEN survey, Fukui et al. 2008) so that contamination by interstellar material in the beam is very unlikely.
The technical justification for the J=3-2 line is given in the Science Goal of the J=2-1 line as it is identical.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The life cycle of dust and gas is one of the main topics in modern astrophysics.
Both intermediate mass Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) stars and Supernovae are believed to be important contributors of dust and gas to the interstellar medium, although their relative contribution remains uncertain. However, we lack evidence of how the gas mass-loss rate of AGB stars depends on luminosity and in particular on metallicity.
A sample of 4 carbon-rich and 2 oxygen-rich very dusty AGB stars in the LMC have been selected for which detailed radiative transfer modelling strongly suggests we will be able to detect the CO J=2-1 and J=3-2 lines, and for which (uncertain) dust mass-loss rates are available. The observations will result in the first direct determination of the gas mass-loss rate in extragalactic, low-metallicity, AGB stars by modelling of the CO lines, and yield, through the expansion velocity, the essential parameter for an accurate determination of the dust mass-loss rate. The observations will provide a critical test of the predictions of dust-driven wind theory on how expansion velocity, dust-to-gas ratio and mass-loss rate depend on metallicity.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is a resubmission of proposal 2013.1.00319S that was rated in the 10-20% bin (graded B), but no succesfull observations have been carried out. We dont request a duplication of data, so any approved SB for Cycle-3 will be withdrawn if executed in Cycle-2.
